Award.AwardTitle: Workshop Proposal: US-China Workshop on Analytical Chemistry Graduate Research and Education; October 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Professors Zheng Ouyang and R. Graham Cooks of Purdue University are hosting a US - China Workshop on analytical chemistry graduate research and education. The workshop will take place at Purdue in West Lafayette, IN, on October 6-7, 2010. US academic analytical chemists will meet Chinese counterparts to exchange information and develop plans for effective research collaboration and improved graduate and undergraduate instruction. Interests common to the two groups will be identified and infrastructure for instrumentation development and analysis services will be discussed. NSF support will ensure participation by a diverse cross-section of junior US faculty.

The ultimate aim of this project is to enhance research progress in technical areas related to measurement science, by identifying technical synergies between the research capabilities in the two countries. It will also provide a mechanism to identify and share best practices in analytical chemistry education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A US/China Workshop was conducted at Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, on the 6th and 7th October, 2010. About 50 leading Chinese and American analytical chemists gathered at Purdue for this first US/China Analytical Chemistry Workshop. The goals of the workshop included strengthening the bonds between the two communities and identifying ways to improve all aspects of the analytical science field, especially infrastructure and research, dissemination of results, and education. The workshop was organized by Prof. Zheng Ouyang, Prof. R. Graham Cooks (Purdue University) and Prof. Xinrong Zhang (Tsinghua University). The key activity at the meeting was breakout discussion groups focused on the topics relevant to education and research in analytical chemistry, especially in areas of strong mutual US/Chinese interest. Specific topics of discussion included Literature and Publications in Analytical Chemistry, Research Trends in Analytical Chemistry, Infrastructure and Instrumentation and, Education and Graduate Experience in Analytical Chemistry. Each of these areas were discussed with the objective of determining steps that are mutually beneficial to the analytical chemistry communities in the two countries as also to identify future course of action to address certain concerns.  The workshop essentially constituted an attempt to increase analytical chemists' understanding of a foreign scientific culture but an indirect effect on the success of ongoing attempts by the participants to increase public understanding of science is likely to be significant.  A follow-up workshop is planned for Beijing in Summer 2012.
